repository.corpname: David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library

did.abstract: William J. Baumol (1922-2017) was an economist and worked as a professor of economics at Princeton University and New York University. This collection consists of his correspondence, research, writings, his collaborations and professional affiliations, and his work as a painter and sculptor.

userestrict.head: Use Restrictions
userestrict.p: The copyright interests in this collection have not been transferred to Duke University. For more information, consult the copyright section of the Regulations and Procedures of the David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: [Identification of item], William J. Baumol Papers, David M. Rubenstein Rare Book & Manuscript Library, Duke University

acqinfo.head: Provenance
acqinfo.p: The papers of William J. Baumol, Princeton and New York University economist, were received as a gift to the Rubenstein Library between 1995 and 2020.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Processed by Shauna Saunders and Paula Jeannet, 2000
Additions processed by Ann G. Langford and Sue-Ellen Katz, 2001
Encoded by Paula Jeannet, Lisa Stark, and Ruth E. Bryan
Later accessions processed and described by Erich Fuchs and Meghan Lyon, 2016.
Additions incorporated and sorted by Jon Cogliano, 2018.

eventgrp.event: Born in New York, N.Y.
Attended first formal art classes sponsored by the Works Progress Administration.
BSS, College of the City of New York; organized extracurricular classes on microeconomics.
Junior Economist, U.S. Department of Agriculture.
Served in U.S. Army, stationed in France.

London School of Economics; Graduate Student and Assistant Lecturer in American Economy and Economic Dynamics. (Lecture notes for the latter formed the basis for his first published book, Economic Dynamics, 1951, 1959, 1970).
Completed University of London Ph. D. thesis, later published as Welfare Economics and the Theory of the State, 1952, 1965. Ph.D. examiners were Marcus Flemming and Lord Lionel Robbins.
Associate Professor of Economics, Princeton University.
Professor of Economics, Princeton University.
Publication of Business Behavior, Value and Growth (second edition 1966).
Publication of Economic Theory and Operations Analysis (later editions in 1965, 1972, 1976).
Chairman, Committee on the Economic Status of the Profession, American Association of University Professors.
Publication with W.G. Bowen of Performing Arts: The Economic Dilemma.
Past Chairman and member, Economic Policy Council, State of New Jersey.
Vice-President, American Association of University Professors.
Professor of Economics and Director, C.V. Starr Center for Applied Economics, New York University.
Publication with W.E. Oates of The Theory of Environmental Policy, (second edition 1988).
President, Eastern Economics Association.
President, Association of Environmental and Resource Economists.
Publication with A.S. Blinder of the first edition of introductory textbook, Economics: Principles and Policies. Later editions in 1982, 1985, 1987, 1991, 1994, and 1998.
President, American Economics Association.
Publication with J.C. Panzar and R.D. Willig of Contestable Markets and the Theory of Industry Structure (second edition 1982).
Editor with wife, Hilda Baumol, of Inflation and the Performing Arts.
Publication of Superfairness: Applications and Theory.
Senior Research Economist and Professor Emeritus of Economics, Princeton University.
Died in New York, NY

scopecontent.head: Collection Overview
scopecontent.p: The William Baumol papers document his career as an economist and artist. The collection provides an overview of his professional activities, including his research on the cost disease, unbalanced growth, productivity growth, entrepreneurship, increasing returns and international trade, anti-trust policy, contestable markets, market structure, macroeconomic theory, and interest rate and monetary theory, among other topics. Baumol's research and writings on the economics of the arts, undertaken and co-authored with his wife Hilda, are included in the collection.

The collection also documents his collaboration and communication with prominent economists such as Maurice Allais, Gary Becker, Alan Blinder, George Dantzig, Robert Dorfman, Milton Friedman, John Kenneth Galbraith, Ralph Gomory, Frank Hahn, Roy Harrod, John Hicks, Ursula Hicks, Samuel Hollander, Nicholas Kaldor, Harold Kuhn, Abba Lerner, Jacob Marschak, Don Patinkin, Lionel Robbins, Joan Robinson, Paul Samuelson, Ralph Turvey, Jacob Viner, and Edward Wolff, among others. Of note is Baumol's longtime collaboration with, and extensive support received from, Sue Anne Batey Blackman.

Along with his scholarship and writings, the collection documents Baumol's leadership roles at the Berkley Center for Entrepreneurship and Innovation and the C.V. Starr Center for Applied Economics at New York University, as well as his extensive expert witness and consulting activities for the Federal Communications Commission, Federal Trade Commission, the Interstate Commerce Commission, the Joint Economic Committee, and the Senate Judiciary Committee, among others. Baumol's consulting was often done through the companies Alderson and Sessions, Mathematica, and Consultants in Industry Economics. His notable expert witness testimonies revolved around regulation in telecommunications (particularly the ATT monopoly), airline ticket prices and sales practices, pricing of railroad freight shipping, and other topics.

Materials from Baumol's teaching at Princeton and New York University, departmental, and committee work are included in the collection. The collection also contains samples of Baumol's artwork, including sketches and paintings.

arrangement.head: Arrangement note
arrangement.p: PROCESSING NOTE: The materials received by Duke University arrived from Professor Baumol's offices at Princeton, New York University, and from his private residence. These were treated as one single accession and the materials from all three shipments have been consolidated. Hence, while the original organization has been mostly preserved at the folder level, at the box level this is not the case. Wherever possible the original folder labels were used in organizing the collection. Notable exceptions to this are the material in the Legal Testimony subseries and materials on the performing arts, government projects, and industry consulting as the bulk of this material was received loose. It was not possible to map every digital file recovered from floppy disks to particular projects, writings, or other files. In these cases generic classifiations were made in the arrangement.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Contains chronological and name files on Baumol's correspondence with various individuals. Correspondence from the earlier decades of Baumol's career was maintained in chronological folders, while name folders were reserved for only some correspondents. Correspondence with notable individuals has been organized into name folders where appropriate, however, correspondence with some notable individuals remains in chronological folders to maintain coherence where conversations took place between multiple individuals. Correspondents of note include: Maurice Allais, Gary Becker, George Dantzig, Robert Dorfman, Milton Friedman, John Kenneth Galbraith, Ralph Gomory, Frank Hahn, Roy Harrod, John Hicks, Ursula Hicks, Samuel Hollander, Nicholas Kaldor, Harold Kuhn, Abba Lerner, Jacob Marschak, Don Patinkin, Lionel Robbins, Joan Robinson, Paul Samuelson, Ralph Turvey, Jacob Viner, and Edward Wolff.

Much of Baumol's correspondence for specific research projects was originally organized with his files for the published work or with the relevant research materials. To maintain the original organization, additional correspondence of this kind can be found in the Writings and Research and Notes series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Includes Baumol's notes and correspondence for research projects, and a portion of his collection of academic writings by others. Research notes include files on Baumol's work on anti-trust policy, the theory of fairness, the cost disease, contestable markets, entrepreneurship, economics and education, history of economic thought, innovation and technological progress, industrial organization, economics of the performing arts, and productivity growth, among other topics. Additional correspondence can be found in the Correspondence and Writings series.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: This series contains copies, reprints, drafts, notes, other documents, and correspondence associated with Baumol's published works. These include: reprints, copies, and drafts of published journal articles and book chapters; copies of books authored by Baumol, as well as drafts for various book projects; and documents from his referee activity for academic journals and publishers. Additional correspondence can be found in the Correspondence and Research and Notes series.
